title: How to Make Chili Beans

methods.name:
Canned Chili Beans[1]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Heat the oil in a large skillet.
steps.description: Add the oil to a large skillet with high sides and warm it on medium heat for several minutes. When ready, the oil should glide easily along the bottom of the pan, but it should not have reached its smoking point yet.

steps.headline: Cook the onion until softened.
steps.description: Add the chopped onion to the hot oil in your skillet and cook for roughly 2 minutes, or until the onion has softened and just begun to brown at the edges. Stir the onions continually as they cook. Do not allow the onions to burn.

steps.headline: Add the kidney beans and tomatoes.
steps.description: Stir the canned kidney beans and canned tomatoes into the skillet, mixing the new ingredients well so that the beans, onions, and tomatoes are all evenly distributed. The kidney beans should be drained and rinsed before you add them, but you should add the full contents of the canned tomatoes, including the liquid.

steps.headline: Stir in the remaining ingredients.
steps.description: Add the tomato paste, golden syrup, oregano, paprika, salt, pepper, and chili powder to the contents of the skillet. Mix thoroughly so that all of the ingredients are evenly combined. Note that golden syrup can be difficult to find. If you do not have it, you can substitute two parts light corn syrup plus one part molasses or equal parts honey and corn syrup.

steps.headline: Bring the chili beans to a boil.
steps.description: Turn the heat up to medium-high until the beans reach a steady boil. Stir frequently to prevent the beans from burning.

steps.headline: Simmer for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Reduce the heat to medium or medium-low so that the beans sit at a mild simmer. Leave the skillet uncovered. Stir the beans occasionally as they simmer to prevent sticking or burning.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: These chili beans can be enjoyed alone, over rice, or used as the base of a quick chili recipe.

methods.name:
Dry Chili Beans[3]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Soak the beans in salted water.
steps.description: Dissolve the salt in 4 cups (1 L) of water. Add the dry beans to the salted water and let soak for a minimum of 8 hours. Soaking the beans softens them and removes many of the gas-inducing compounds they contain. Sort through the beans to remove any broken or irregular beans, stones, and debris from the mix before soaking them. The beans can soak for a maximum of 24 hours.

steps.headline: Rinse and drain the beans.
steps.description: Drain the beans and transfer them to a colander. Rinse them under clean, running water, then let drain again. Discard the soaking liquid after you drain the beans.

steps.headline: Heat the olive oil.
steps.description: Heat the oil in a large skillet with deep sides over medium-high heat. Wait a minute or two for the oil to heat, but do not let it reach its smoking point.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion until soft.
steps.description: Add the chopped onion to the hot oil and cook, stirring continuously, until it begins to softened. The onion can turn clear or golden, but do not let it brown or burn.

steps.headline: Add the taco seasoning mix and garlic powder.
steps.description: Sprinkle the seasonings over the onion and stir well to coat. Let cook for another 1 minute, stirring frequently to prevent burning.

steps.headline: Add the tomato paste, vegetable broth, beans, and remaining water.
steps.description: Add the tomato paste and stir to combine it with the seasoned onions before stirring in the vegetable broth. Add the remaining water and pre-soaked beans after that. If the mixture seems lumpy after you stir in the vegetable broth, whisk it to remove the lumps before adding the water and beans.

steps.headline: Boil the chili beans.
steps.description: Let the beans reach a steady boil at medium-high heat before reducing the heat to medium-low. Stir frequently to prevent burning.

steps.headline: Let simmer up to 2 hours.
steps.description: Cook the beans until they become tender. This may take as little as 1 hour and 30 minutes. Leave the skillet uncovered as the beans simmer. Stir the beans occasionally as they cook.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Remove the finished chili beans from the heat and serve warm. These beans can be used as a base for simple chili, or they could serve as a side dish for Mexican food, burgers, or hot dogs.

methods.name:
Slow Cooker Chili Beans[4]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Heat the oil in a large skillet with high sides.
steps.description: Add the oil to your skillet and heat over medium heat for a couple of minutes. Allow the oil to get hot, but do not bring it up to its smoking point. When the oil glides around the pan even more easily than it does at room temperature, it is ready to use.

steps.headline: Cook the onion until soft.
steps.description: Add the chopped onion to the hot oil and cook, stirring constantly, until it becomes soft. The onion can begin to turn translucent, but do not allow it to brown or burn.

steps.headline: Stir in the seasonings.
steps.description: Add the garlic powder, chili powder, cumin, paprika, and salt to the onion. Stir well to coat evenly.

steps.headline: Add the tomato sauce and diced tomatoes.
steps.description: Add both tomato products, undrained, to the skillet and stir well to combine. Use your spatula or a wooden mixing spoon to scrape any brown bits from the bottom of your pan at this point.

steps.headline: Simmer for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Let this mixture simmer for a few minutes while the flavors combine. Stir occasionally. Do not cover.

steps.headline: Transfer the mixture to the slow cooker along with the beans and bay leaf.
steps.description: Transfer the tomato and onion mixture to the slow cooker and stir in the canned beans until evenly distributed. Stick the bay leaf into the mixture toward the center. Make sure that the beans are drained and rinsed before you add them.

steps.headline: Cook on low for 4 to 6 hours.
steps.description: Cover the slow cooker and let the chili beans cook until very tender. Keep the slow cooker covered for the entire process. Do not uncover the slow cooker to stir the beans while they cook. The chili beans can also be cooked on high for 2 to 3 hours.

steps.headline: Mash some of the beans before serving.
steps.description: Use a wooden spoon to mash one-third to one-half of the beans. Stir well. Doing this will create a thicker consistency, but it is not necessary if you prefer a thinner broth.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: These chili beans can be enjoyed as a main dish or as a side. You can also add cooked meat to them to create a traditional chili.

steps.headline: Place the beans and 2 cups (500 ml) of water in a microwave-safe container.
steps.description: Cover the dish with microwave-safe plastic wrap. A glass casserole dish will usually suffice, but make sure that the dish is safe for microwave use. Note that most plastic wrap is safe for microwave use, but not all plastic wrap is. Check yours to verify that it can be used in the microwave before using it.

steps.headline: Microwave for 15 minutes on high.
steps.description: If your microwave does not have a rotating tray, pause the cooking time halfway through, turn the dish 180 degrees, and continue cooking. Watch the beans carefully as you microwave them to make sure that the plastic wrap does not melt.

steps.headline: Let sit for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Carefully remove the dish of beans from the microwave and let them stand in the hot water undisturbed.

steps.headline: Add additional hot water and let sit for 1 hour.
steps.description: Stir in another 2 cups (500 ml) of very hot water. Let the beans sit for another 1 hour.

steps.headline: Drain the beans.
steps.description: Transfer the beans to a colander to drain them. Rinse the beans under warm running water after draining them. Discard the water the beans soaked in.

steps.headline: Microwave the vegetable oil for 1 minute on high.
steps.description: Place the oil in a microwave-safe baking dish for 1 minute to heat it. Most glass baking dishes are microwave-safe, but you should always check your dish to make sure. Do not use a metal baking dish.

steps.headline: Add the remaining ingredients, except for the water and tomato.
steps.description: Stir the chopped onions, garlic powder, bay leaf, chili powder, cumin, Creole seasoning, and salt to the baking dish. Mix well to combine and coat in oil.

steps.headline: Microwave for 4 minutes on high.
steps.description: Cook the onions and seasonings on high to soften the onion. Leave the dish uncovered.

steps.headline: Add the beans and remaining water.
steps.description: Add the pre-soaked beans and 4 cups (1 L) of hot water to the baking dish, stirring well to combine. Cover the baking dish with microwave-safe plastic wrap.

steps.headline: Microwave on high for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Cook the chili beans until tender. If your tray does not rotate, turn the dish once in the middle of the cooking process so that the beans cook evenly. Watch the chili beans as they cook to ensure that the plastic wrap does not melt.

steps.headline: Let stand.
steps.description: Remove the cooked beans from the microwave and let stand, covered, for 15 minutes. Uncover the baking dish carefully when the time comes. Be careful, or else you may burn yourself on the steam.

steps.headline: Stir in the diced tomato.
steps.description: Stir the diced tomato into the chili beans until evenly combined.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: The hot chili beans can be enjoyed on their own, added to cooked meat to form a traditional chili, or served as a side dish.

text:
Canned Chili Beans[1]
	X
		Research source Heat the oil in a large skillet. Add the oil to a large skillet with high sides and warm it on medium heat for several minutes. When ready, the oil should glide easily along the bottom of the pan, but it should not have reached its smoking point yet. Cook the onion until softened. Add the chopped onion to the hot oil in your skillet and cook for roughly 2 minutes, or until the onion has softened and just begun to brown at the edges. Stir the onions continually as they cook. Do not allow the onions to burn. Add the kidney beans and tomatoes. Stir the canned kidney beans and canned tomatoes into the skillet, mixing the new ingredients well so that the beans, onions, and tomatoes are all evenly distributed. The kidney beans should be drained and rinsed before you add them, but you should add the full contents of the canned tomatoes, including the liquid. Stir in the remaining ingredients. Add the tomato paste, golden syrup, oregano, paprika, salt, pepper, and chili powder to the contents of the skillet. Mix thoroughly so that all of the ingredients are evenly combined. Note that golden syrup can be difficult to find. If you do not have it, you can substitute two parts light corn syrup plus one part molasses or equal parts honey and corn syrup. Bring the chili beans to a boil. Turn the heat up to medium-high until the beans reach a steady boil. Stir frequently to prevent the beans from burning. Simmer for 20 minutes. Reduce the heat to medium or medium-low so that the beans sit at a mild simmer. Leave the skillet uncovered. Stir the beans occasionally as they simmer to prevent sticking or burning. Serve. These chili beans can be enjoyed alone, over rice, or used as the base of a quick chili recipe. Dry Chili Beans[3]
	X
		Research source Soak the beans in salted water. Dissolve the salt in 4 cups (1 L) of water. Add the dry beans to the salted water and let soak for a minimum of 8 hours. Soaking the beans softens them and removes many of the gas-inducing compounds they contain. Sort through the beans to remove any broken or irregular beans, stones, and debris from the mix before soaking them. The beans can soak for a maximum of 24 hours. Rinse and drain the beans. Drain the beans and transfer them to a colander. Rinse them under clean, running water, then let drain again. Discard the soaking liquid after you drain the beans. Heat the olive oil. Heat the oil in a large skillet with deep sides over medium-high heat. Wait a minute or two for the oil to heat, but do not let it reach its smoking point. Sauté the onion until soft. Add the chopped onion to the hot oil and cook, stirring continuously, until it begins to softened. The onion can turn clear or golden, but do not let it brown or burn. Add the taco seasoning mix and garlic powder. Sprinkle the seasonings over the onion and stir well to coat. Let cook for another 1 minute, stirring frequently to prevent burning. Add the tomato paste, vegetable broth, beans, and remaining water. Add the tomato paste and stir to combine it with the seasoned onions before stirring in the vegetable broth. Add the remaining water and pre-soaked beans after that. If the mixture seems lumpy after you stir in the vegetable broth, whisk it to remove the lumps before adding the water and beans. Boil the chili beans. Let the beans reach a steady boil at medium-high heat before reducing the heat to medium-low. Stir frequently to prevent burning. Let simmer up to 2 hours. Cook the beans until they become tender. This may take as little as 1 hour and 30 minutes. Leave the skillet uncovered as the beans simmer. Stir the beans occasionally as they cook. Serve. Remove the finished chili beans from the heat and serve warm. These beans can be used as a base for simple chili, or they could serve as a side dish for Mexican food, burgers, or hot dogs. Slow Cooker Chili Beans[4]
	X
		Research source Heat the oil in a large skillet with high sides. Add the oil to your skillet and heat over medium heat for a couple of minutes. Allow the oil to get hot, but do not bring it up to its smoking point. When the oil glides around the pan even more easily than it does at room temperature, it is ready to use. Cook the onion until soft. Add the chopped onion to the hot oil and cook, stirring constantly, until it becomes soft. The onion can begin to turn translucent, but do not allow it to brown or burn. Stir in the seasonings. Add the garlic powder, chili powder, cumin, paprika, and salt to the onion. Stir well to coat evenly. Add the tomato sauce and diced tomatoes. Add both tomato products, undrained, to the skillet and stir well to combine. Use your spatula or a wooden mixing spoon to scrape any brown bits from the bottom of your pan at this point. Simmer for 5 minutes. Let this mixture simmer for a few minutes while the flavors combine. Stir occasionally. Do not cover. Transfer the mixture to the slow cooker along with the beans and bay leaf. Transfer the tomato and onion mixture to the slow cooker and stir in the canned beans until evenly distributed. Stick the bay leaf into the mixture toward the center. Make sure that the beans are drained and rinsed before you add them. Cook on low for 4 to 6 hours. Cover the slow cooker and let the chili beans cook until very tender. Keep the slow cooker covered for the entire process. Do not uncover the slow cooker to stir the beans while they cook. The chili beans can also be cooked on high for 2 to 3 hours. Mash some of the beans before serving. Use a wooden spoon to mash one-third to one-half of the beans. Stir well. Doing this will create a thicker consistency, but it is not necessary if you prefer a thinner broth. Serve. These chili beans can be enjoyed as a main dish or as a side. You can also add cooked meat to them to create a traditional chili. Microwave Chili Beans Place the beans and 2 cups (500 ml) of water in a microwave-safe container. Cover the dish with microwave-safe plastic wrap. A glass casserole dish will usually suffice, but make sure that the dish is safe for microwave use. Note that most plastic wrap is safe for microwave use, but not all plastic wrap is. Check yours to verify that it can be used in the microwave before using it. Microwave for 15 minutes on high. If your microwave does not have a rotating tray, pause the cooking time halfway through, turn the dish 180 degrees, and continue cooking. Watch the beans carefully as you microwave them to make sure that the plastic wrap does not melt. Let sit for 5 minutes. Carefully remove the dish of beans from the microwave and let them stand in the hot water undisturbed. Add additional hot water and let sit for 1 hour. Stir in another 2 cups (500 ml) of very hot water. Let the beans sit for another 1 hour. Drain the beans. Transfer the beans to a colander to drain them. Rinse the beans under warm running water after draining them. Discard the water the beans soaked in. Microwave the vegetable oil for 1 minute on high. Place the oil in a microwave-safe baking dish for 1 minute to heat it. Most glass baking dishes are microwave-safe, but you should always check your dish to make sure. Do not use a metal baking dish. Add the remaining ingredients, except for the water and tomato. Stir the chopped onions, garlic powder, bay leaf, chili powder, cumin, Creole seasoning, and salt to the baking dish. Mix well to combine and coat in oil. Microwave for 4 minutes on high. Cook the onions and seasonings on high to soften the onion. Leave the dish uncovered. Add the beans and remaining water. Add the pre-soaked beans and 4 cups (1 L) of hot water to the baking dish, stirring well to combine. Cover the baking dish with microwave-safe plastic wrap. Microwave on high for 30 minutes. Cook the chili beans until tender. If your tray does not rotate, turn the dish once in the middle of the cooking process so that the beans cook evenly. Watch the chili beans as they cook to ensure that the plastic wrap does not melt. Let stand. Remove the cooked beans from the microwave and let stand, covered, for 15 minutes. Uncover the baking dish carefully when the time comes. Be careful, or else you may burn yourself on the steam. Stir in the diced tomato. Stir the diced tomato into the chili beans until evenly combined. Serve. The hot chili beans can be enjoyed on their own, added to cooked meat to form a traditional chili, or served as a side dish.
sentences:
Canned Chili Beans[1]
	X
		Research source Heat the oil in a large skillet.
Add the oil to a large skillet with high sides and warm it on medium heat for several minutes.
When ready, the oil should glide easily along the bottom of the pan, but it should not have reached its smoking point yet.
Cook the onion until softened.
Add the chopped onion to the hot oil in your skillet and cook for roughly 2 minutes, or until the onion has softened and just begun to brown at the edges.
Stir the onions continually as they cook.
Do not allow the onions to burn.
Add the kidney beans and tomatoes.
Stir the canned kidney beans and canned tomatoes into the skillet, mixing the new ingredients well so that the beans, onions, and tomatoes are all evenly distributed.
The kidney beans should be drained and rinsed before you add them, but you should add the full contents of the canned tomatoes, including the liquid.
Stir in the remaining ingredients.
Add the tomato paste, golden syrup, oregano, paprika, salt, pepper, and chili powder to the contents of the skillet.
Mix thoroughly so that all of the ingredients are evenly combined.
Note that golden syrup can be difficult to find.
If you do not have it, you can substitute two parts light corn syrup plus one part molasses or equal parts honey and corn syrup.
Bring the chili beans to a boil.
Turn the heat up to medium-high until the beans reach a steady boil.
Stir frequently to prevent the beans from burning.
Simmer for 20 minutes.
Reduce the heat to medium or medium-low so that the beans sit at a mild simmer.
Leave the skillet uncovered.
Stir the beans occasionally as they simmer to prevent sticking or burning.
Serve.
These chili beans can be enjoyed alone, over rice, or used as the base of a quick chili recipe.

Dry Chili Beans[3]
	X
		Research source Soak the beans in salted water.
Dissolve the salt in 4 cups (1 L) of water.
Add the dry beans to the salted water and let soak for a minimum of 8 hours.
Soaking the beans softens them and removes many of the gas-inducing compounds they contain.
Sort through the beans to remove any broken or irregular beans, stones, and debris from the mix before soaking them.
The beans can soak for a maximum of 24 hours.
Rinse and drain the beans.
Drain the beans and transfer them to a colander.
Rinse them under clean, running water, then let drain again.
Discard the soaking liquid after you drain the beans.
Heat the olive oil.
Heat the oil in a large skillet with deep sides over medium-high heat.
Wait a minute or two for the oil to heat, but do not let it reach its smoking point.
Sauté the onion until soft.
Add the chopped onion to the hot oil and cook, stirring continuously, until it begins to softened.
The onion can turn clear or golden, but do not let it brown or burn.
Add the taco seasoning mix and garlic powder.
Sprinkle the seasonings over the onion and stir well to coat.
Let cook for another 1 minute, stirring frequently to prevent burning.
Add the tomato paste, vegetable broth, beans, and remaining water.
Add the tomato paste and stir to combine it with the seasoned onions before stirring in the vegetable broth.
Add the remaining water and pre-soaked beans after that.
If the mixture seems lumpy after you stir in the vegetable broth, whisk it to remove the lumps before adding the water and beans.
Boil the chili beans.
Let the beans reach a steady boil at medium-high heat before reducing the heat to medium-low.
Stir frequently to prevent burning.
Let simmer up to 2 hours.
Cook the beans until they become tender.
This may take as little as 1 hour and 30 minutes.
Leave the skillet uncovered as the beans simmer.
Stir the beans occasionally as they cook.
Serve.
Remove the finished chili beans from the heat and serve warm.
These beans can be used as a base for simple chili, or they could serve as a side dish for Mexican food, burgers, or hot dogs.

Slow Cooker Chili Beans[4]
	X
		Research source Heat the oil in a large skillet with high sides.
Add the oil to your skillet and heat over medium heat for a couple of minutes.
Allow the oil to get hot, but do not bring it up to its smoking point.
When the oil glides around the pan even more easily than it does at room temperature, it is ready to use.
Cook the onion until soft.
Add the chopped onion to the hot oil and cook, stirring constantly, until it becomes soft.
The onion can begin to turn translucent, but do not allow it to brown or burn.
Stir in the seasonings.
Add the garlic powder, chili powder, cumin, paprika, and salt to the onion.
Stir well to coat evenly.
Add the tomato sauce and diced tomatoes.
Add both tomato products, undrained, to the skillet and stir well to combine.
Use your spatula or a wooden mixing spoon to scrape any brown bits from the bottom of your pan at this point.
Simmer for 5 minutes.
Let this mixture simmer for a few minutes while the flavors combine.
Stir occasionally.
Do not cover.
Transfer the mixture to the slow cooker along with the beans and bay leaf.
Transfer the tomato and onion mixture to the slow cooker and stir in the canned beans until evenly distributed.
Stick the bay leaf into the mixture toward the center.
Make sure that the beans are drained and rinsed before you add them.
Cook on low for 4 to 6 hours.
Cover the slow cooker and let the chili beans cook until very tender.
Keep the slow cooker covered for the entire process.
Do not uncover the slow cooker to stir the beans while they cook.
The chili beans can also be cooked on high for 2 to 3 hours.
Mash some of the beans before serving.
Use a wooden spoon to mash one-third to one-half of the beans.
Stir well.
Doing this will create a thicker consistency, but it is not necessary if you prefer a thinner broth.
Serve.
These chili beans can be enjoyed as a main dish or as a side.
You can also add cooked meat to them to create a traditional chili.
Microwave Chili Beans Place the beans and 2 cups (500 ml) of water in a microwave-safe container.
Cover the dish with microwave-safe plastic wrap.
A glass casserole dish will usually suffice, but make sure that the dish is safe for microwave use.
Note that most plastic wrap is safe for microwave use, but not all plastic wrap is.
Check yours to verify that it can be used in the microwave before using it.
Microwave for 15 minutes on high.
If your microwave does not have a rotating tray, pause the cooking time halfway through, turn the dish 180 degrees, and continue cooking.
Watch the beans carefully as you microwave them to make sure that the plastic wrap does not melt.
Let sit for 5 minutes.
Carefully remove the dish of beans from the microwave and let them stand in the hot water undisturbed.
Add additional hot water and let sit for 1 hour.
Stir in another 2 cups (500 ml) of very hot water.
Let the beans sit for another 1 hour.
Drain the beans.
Transfer the beans to a colander to drain them.
Rinse the beans under warm running water after draining them.
Discard the water the beans soaked in.
Microwave the vegetable oil for 1 minute on high.
Place the oil in a microwave-safe baking dish for 1 minute to heat it.
Most glass baking dishes are microwave-safe, but you should always check your dish to make sure.
Do not use a metal baking dish.
Add the remaining ingredients, except for the water and tomato.
Stir the chopped onions, garlic powder, bay leaf, chili powder, cumin, Creole seasoning, and salt to the baking dish.
Mix well to combine and coat in oil.
Microwave for 4 minutes on high.
Cook the onions and seasonings on high to soften the onion.
Leave the dish uncovered.
Add the beans and remaining water.
Add the pre-soaked beans and 4 cups (1 L) of hot water to the baking dish, stirring well to combine.
Cover the baking dish with microwave-safe plastic wrap.
Microwave on high for 30 minutes.
Cook the chili beans until tender.
If your tray does not rotate, turn the dish once in the middle of the cooking process so that the beans cook evenly.
Watch the chili beans as they cook to ensure that the plastic wrap does not melt.
Let stand.
Remove the cooked beans from the microwave and let stand, covered, for 15 minutes.
Uncover the baking dish carefully when the time comes.
Be careful, or else you may burn yourself on the steam.
Stir in the diced tomato.
Stir the diced tomato into the chili beans until evenly combined.
Serve.
The hot chili beans can be enjoyed on their own, added to cooked meat to form a traditional chili, or served as a side dish.
tyn_section: Large skillet with deep sides or stockpot
